column2: You can find useful tips and information on Insight's website .

Your most common questions will be answered within these specially prepared downloads .

From passports and visa questions to what and how to pack for your holiday .
Our On-Tour Recommendations : A selection of recommendations on places to shop , dine and sightsee during your
Stay In Touch and Save With ekit : Get your prepaid international phone and SIM to stay in touch and save while on tour .
Control the costs of your calls , texts and data , and don't get surprised by large phone bills when you return home .
London Reception Centre : 12 July 2011 marks the start of an exciting new era for our London Reception Centre , as we open the
On Tour : To ensure your journey is comfortable and enjoyable with Insight Vacations our on-tour tips to help minimize
European Distance Chart : Classified into countries to guide you on your journeys with Insight Vacations , find the
I am greatly influenced by the tips you provided .
It has lots of things to follow and for the tour planning .
Last edited by : John - Moderator , 11 June 2012 21:44
I was disappointed that the European Distance Chart doesn't list any of the cities on our tour : Warsaw , Russia and the
I am about to join the Spain\/Portugal tour .
Will I need a jacket for the evening ?
Really very helpful advices to make travel easy and stress    free .
there are many vacation rental companies available online for booking your vacation rental But few of them are fake ones
You will great offers for Saint Lucia and very good services ,
Auusie travellers to the above countries .
what are your plans with money ... are you just taking credit card or will you carry local currency before the trip ?
It 's mainly geared towards American travelers , but has some useful info on ATM locations which you may like to consider .
I 'm currently finishing the Turkey part of my trip , and about to start the Greek half .
Wrote some tips here .
I will take some amount of cash and will use credit card for most of the expenses
quote : credit card
credit card is better but always a fear with it of loosing .
Last edited by : John - Moderator , 31 May 2012 16:39
We did not use credit cards at all in either Egypt or Turkey .
They are useless for small purchases in the markets and for drinks or a bite to eat for lunch .
Could n't get the cash in NZ before we left , but had no trouble at all using ATMs in both countries .
We used both credit card and ATMs in Turkey with no problems using just commonsense on where and when to use either .
We used credit cards and atm 's in Egypt without any trouble - also kept small amounts of local currency for small purchases .
For others that have been to these countries when would you suggest was a good time ?
I was thinking perhaps September or March\/April .
I like warm weather but after touring this European summer hubby did n't think that much of the high 30s we had or the 44 in Turkey -LRB- due to his asthma -RRB- .
He would be much happier with high 20s .
I know this question is difficult to answer as every season is so changeable from previous years
The weather was beautiful and not too hot .
We were able to wear shorts some days and even go for a swim .
In Spain it was kind of hot and we tried to put the air on and were told they only run it in July and Aug. .
I think it was in the mid 80 there and around 80 in Morocco .
Hotels were very comfortable and very nice .
We went there the around the 20th of April a few years ago .
I went mid-September -LRB- 2005 -RRB- and the weather was great , not too hot or too cool-think mostly in the mid 20 's and only had rain on 1 day in the afternoon .
I 'm not a shorts kind of person , spent most of the time in capris , jeans , short sleeved t-shirts .
You 'll get the most heat in Morocco but even that was around the mid to high 20 's .
You 'll love it !
Hi , we went on this tour in the middle of April a few years ago , we had good weather the whole time from low 20s to high 20s in Morocco .
There were fields of wildflowers in Morocco which was a real surprise .
This was a wonderful tour you will have a great time .
I was wondering when Americas school holidays start and finish .
Areas of Montana and Wyoming I 'm going to a ranch before my tour .
Last edited by : Allison , 14 January 2008 23:33
That depends on the school district and there are a lot of them .
Generally the school vacations start about the first week in June and end about the last week in August .
As Pauline wrote , each individual school district sets their own dates .
The ones I noted are in Northern California .
New York schools end the last week of June and return first week of September .
I have just been reading the Travel tips for Australians and in particular about `` Secure Sentinel '' for protecting credit\/debit cards etc. and other travel documents whilst away .
Has anyone had any experience with this company and is it worth joining for 12 months ?
I hate to think what would happen if either myself or my husband had our wallets stolen whilst away .
We will be traveling with Insight for 2 weeks in Switzerland but then we have another 5 weeks in Europe .
We consider it cheap insurance in case anything goes wrong , which we hope never does .
We updated everything before we went away last year
Make sure you add your passports
We think this service is great value
We have been members of Secure Sentinel for a few years now .
I have had cause only once to use the service when I had my purse stolen from work .
Just one phone call
It was a great relief not to have to all the ringing around .
It was stressful enough as it was !
Thanks for the info Midge .
We have decided to join hopefully only for `` peace of mind '' but if something does goes wrong we will be able to get prompt action on the canceling of our cards etc. .
We really enjoyed our time in Switzerland
We are going on the Romantic European trip starting on the 11th May 2008 and need to know if it will be warm enough for 3\/4 pants and t-shirts or will we need warmer stuff .
What will the average temperature be .
The weather can be all over the place , I would take both summer and winter and some in between a warm jacket , layers .
I 've had snow , rain , nice sunny days but cool and then some days in the 30s .
Be prepared for anything .
Tempeture mid teens - 30s .
The hotel rooms are usually warm and some do n't have AC .
I aways travel in May , June .
Have a look at my topic Great weather site under travel advice .
Hi Travelfor 2 .
It has some good info it may be of some help .

My wife and I are taking the Highlights of Eastern Europe tour starting Sep 27 , before starting the tour we are staying in Paris for four days we have been to Paris before but only staying at the Insight tour hotel .
Can anyone recommend a hotel in Paris which is central and rates which are reasonable , we relise rooms are small which is ok so long as they are clean and convienent to attractions .
Following our tour in June friends who were touring with us stayed at the Hotel Hospitel , right next to Notre Dame .
It is actually part of an old Hospital building .
They said it was an excellent place to stay and you are certainly close to everything there .
In 2002 I stayed at the Keppler , which was very reasonable and in walking distance to all the main attractions .
It 's small and simple , but has beds and bathrooms which is all you need .
I think the price back in 2002 was equivalent to about $ 40 something American dollars a night .
We are also first timers to Paris July 08 and our travel agent suggested the Regence Etoile near Arche De Triumphe about $ 140 a night Cheers from Kay
quote : Originally posted by geordie01 :
There is a lovely hotel called `` Hotel des Grandes _•À__coles '' which is very central and charming .
I highly recommend it
My boyfriend and i will be traveling in Spain for 14 days in July .
i 've never been to Spain , and there 's no way to go everywhere i want to see in just two weeks .
so , i 'm looking for the best sort of `` introductory '' itinerary .
i 'm thinking of flying into madrid and out of Barcelona , or vice versa .
though round trip from just one city is a possibility as well .
we think Madrid and Barcelona are two must-go for beginner and have explored http://www.allmadrid.com and http://www.gobarcelona.biz but still have no specific idea about our trip .

we are in out early 30 's and ideally , the trip would include a combination of a good deal of historical sight-seeing ; some places good for taking in -LRB- or participating in -RRB- interesting culture and food ; and a little bit of beach\/relaxation -LRB- preferably toward the end , though not necessary -RRB- .
we 're also interested in a day or 2 really off the beaten tourist path .
we 're both native spanish speakers and would be interested in visiting a small town or village away from most tourists to sort of see the ` real ' spain .
also , should we take into consideration the July heat and stick to northern\/cooler regions ?
it 's hard , because there are so many places to go , but we also want to take it slow , have a relaxing vacation , and not spend every minute in transit from one place to the next !
Thanks in advance for your recommendations .
Go to the Insight home page -LRB- to the right of Contact Us below -RRB- and look in the European tours - you should find 3 or 4 to choose from .
fendi , it 's sounds like you are traveling independently and not doing an Insight tour .
Check out http://www.fodors.com/ as they cater for the ` non tour ' traveller .
I think once you 're in Spain , you ca n't miss spain travel and cadiz .
They are all unforgettable places to visit and I 'd love to go back for awhile .
If you 're in Barcelona be sure to check out the Picasso museum as well and I think the best way to get around Spain is by train , and you can see the beautiful scene along the way .
Have a good trip in Spain !
Sounds like more of that Spain spam we 've had on and off for awhile now .
Laj , I think you are correct .
I was wondering if it would be a better idea to bring all Euros or should I bring some of the local currency and if so , how much ?
Also , is it relatively easy to exchange Euro 's for the local currency when I am in Prague , Budapest and Vienna ?
The currency for Austria is the euro anyway .
While the other 2 have local currency I believe they accept euro as well .
the best bet is to either get a currency pack which will contain the correct currency or use the atm for Prague and Budapest that is what I did and it was not trouble at all .
In fact I did not need any currency in Budapest as I did all the optionals and used credit card .
For Prague I took out about 600 krone but 400 would have been enough .
I bought a quick lunch and still had some money over to buy a few little things .
Thank you Neice
Jos , when you say currency pack - what exactly do you mean - is this something that you can do with Insight while on tour .
Sorry , I am new to this .
Insight offer you the opportunity to purchase a starter pack of the different currencies you 'll use on your tour .
We did n't purchase one , but it would have been helpful on our trip .
We relied mostly on ATMs and just exchanged some of our Euros in Budapest and Prague .
I found we needed to have some local currency for the villages we visited and some of the smaller stores .
It made it easier .
If you buy in Euros , you 'll mostly get the change in the local currency and it 's a bit confusing .
So avoiding using Euro if you are close to leaving .
You 'll be left with all the change .
When departing Poland and the Czech Republic and Hungary , I just exchanged whatever local currency I had left , back into Euro at the border exchange shops .
Have Insight offered ` currency ' packs since the Euro came into being ?
I did the ` Highlights of Eastern Europe ' back in 2002 and it was n't offered then .
I took Euro 's with me and exchanged some of them at the borders , for the local currency .

I found the eaiest way to work out what you need in the local currency is to do some window shopping and having a look on the exchange rate boards that are displayed at banks etc. and then work out from there what you need .
Even a local cafe will display the price of a toasted sandwich etc. .
So by doing that it will give you a pretty good idea .
I have only ever had starter currency packs offered for European tours strarting and finishing in London .
In fact I have not had starter packs offered for quite some time now .
We are planning to do the Britain and Ireland Discovery 22 day tour in August next year and would like some feedback from someone who has done this previously .
Any pros or cons would be appreciated .
We are tossing up between Insight and another company .
Any help would be greatly appreciated .
It was great , there was a lot to see and discover .
You do need to be aware that some of the hotels on this tour are not as good as that is all that is available in some of the remote areas .
But the sights are well worth it .
My favorites would be Orkney and the hotel in Thurso is pub standard but worth it for the day trip , skye is of the same standard but again the area is lovely .
I think this tour on the whole is a good one with lots to see , and like any tour some things dont suit everyone .
I did the tour earlier this year .
Calli , I found one tour tale for you to read about the tour , under Tour Tales , then `` Where are all the Tales ? ''
Britain and Ireland Discovery
We are also planning to do this tour in July and was wondering if you could post something about your tour in the Tour Tales posts .
I think on this tour there was enough time to soak up the atmosphere of the places visited and that made it that more special .
I will try and write a tale , I did not keep a diary on this tour .
I was having such a lovely time that writing was just in the way , and so dont have an accurate account of all the places visited , and they were numerous .
I have to say that the weather wasnt with us and it rained most of the time , but made no difference it was still lovely .
Thank you so much for recommending this tour tale .
I thouroughly enjoyed reading about the experiences and it has given me a much better understanding of the tour and what to expect .
Jos I know what you mean about trying to keep a dairy on holiday .
I started but as there is always plenty to do i forgot to keep it up .
Too Busy Sightseeing .
As a first time bus traveller , has anyone out there done this European Grandeur Tour and can offer any advice or travel trips .
e.g. length of tour , hotels , optional extras , tour directors , etc.
The only reason we did the Explorer instead was that 3 weeks on a coach was long enough for us .
Both tours are similar except that the Grandeur goes to Spain .
Two night stops are great as you do get to see something of the town or city you are in .
All hotels were fine , meals a bit mixed and fellow travellers wonderful .
Our TD was very organised and that helped a lot in getting us into places before the crowds .
The weather also treated us very well and Mt Pilatus and Eagles Nest were both amazing - we could see for miles .
We did most of the optionals and were pleased that we did .
Some are better than others but being with the group was part of the fun .
As a fellow Kiwi I can really recommend touring with Insight .
Friends of ours did the `` Grandeur '' in 2005 and my husband and myself did the European Explorer in June this year .
So it really comes down to personal choice .
I have written a report on the European Explorer in `` Tour Tales '' and you may find that this will give you an idea of day by day touring .
Would love to go again , maybe in 2009 .
We are all booked for the 18th September 2007 so it is all rather exciting now we have made our decision .
So if any of you are doing an extended tour to Jordan make sure you research it before signing up for it .
Have just returned from Wonders of Egypt tour , absolutely fabulous and great hotels and tour director .
Ca n't say the same about Jordan .
Tour guide Tony , not that great , rather rude etc and accom with hotels not good .
Most of us on the tour were extremely unhappy with Jordan tour but to see the City of Petra amazing .
Sorry to hear the Jordan part of your tour was not up to scratch .
I 've not read a tour tale since Tangatta 's and it was n't all that complementary .
We 've booked the Jordan Experience tour starting 4Apr2008 .
It 's the start of our `` Saved for over 4 years and blowing it all in a month '' holiday .
If you get some time could you either post a Tour Tale or outline some of the problem area 's with the tour .
We wo n't be changing our booking but the more prepared we are the better we can cope with any problems .
I was thinking of Jordan next year , you do n't think that maybe it was made worse because it came after Egypt and the Tour Directors there are so good ?
Which TD did you have in Egypt by the way ?

I think that the tour guide was no interested in stopping to show us interesting things , he continually talked about himself etc , was rude especially to woman and not interested in participating with the crew he had to guide .

There were stuff ups with late comers arriving at 10pm and no dinner , the tour guide not bothering to come and sort out anything only by phone with no outcomes , he was extremely distant and difficult to approach , accomodation was not 4-5 star as previously advertised with Insight with most rooms where ever we stayed having faulty air con , taps , sinks etc and this was across the board , not just a few people , breakfast cold , and that is just to name a few things .
Like I said the Rose City of Petra is really the main thing in Jordan and you will have to hire a private tour guide to do the 45 kms  approx  to the dead sea .
Mustapha was the one in Egypt .
Hi , I have never done the express check in for any other tour , but thought I will this time .
Can anyone tell me please before I start the process if they ask for the transfer details to and from the airports please .
I still have a few details to sort with my TA and do n't wo n't to get part way through this and have to stop , many thanks !
I do n't believe that they do ask you about transfers , from what I remember -LRB- did it a month or two ago most recently -RRB- .
There is a slight possibility I might have forgotten though I do n't think so

Thank you so much !
will be in chat room for once ... .
There has to be an easier way !
I stayed on this morning and went back and forth from BB to chat but never saw your message .
I was actually on 5:45 a.m. EDT .
While I am on , I never see any change in names\/notices on the BB .
If I log OFF and then back ON , then I see new names .
It 's 1:45 p.m. EDT - are you on now ?
Since we both live in the same time zone , we need to set a time .
Not at all on Sunday - too many obligations and must watch football !
Then I am going out of town -LRB- not out of country -RRB- .
When I get back , I 'll track you down and we 'll set up a time -- no matter what the screen says .
I know `` community time '' and `` local time '' and they seem to change as to whether or not we are logged on or not .
I 'll get back to you in about a week .
Hey , it says you are on NOW .
I 'll give it a try in the chat room .
To all who just read those lines -- it worked !
Last edited by : September , 03 November 2007 23:09
Hello one and all .
I hope all of your traveling plans are coming along well .
We prebooked for Easy Pace Spain and Portugal and now that the brochures are avail electronically we are being quoted a much higher amount by my travel agent .
We assume that the price quoted in the brochure for tour and air is accurate unless your departure was not from Toronto -LRB- than you had to add on -RRB- but we are quoted $ 500 more per person !
Has anyone else ever been charged more than the quoted price in the brochure including air ?
Any info or feedback is appreciated !

I have booked air twice through Insight and in both instances paid more than the brochure price to get the airline and routing that I wanted , not taking into account the additional amount I would have to pay anyway to get to Toronto or Montreal .
However , I have never paid anywhere near $ 500 over brochure price .

I found that the flights at the brochure price are often airlines or routings that I would not choose -- for example , while I do n't mind flying KLM , I do not like that bus ride to Montreal to make the connection .

You need to find out exactly what your TA is basing the airfare quote on - and I 'm not sure that the Insight air price includes taxes and surcharges , etc. which these days can easily add $ 300 + to the cost of a flight to Europe .
I paid almost $ 400 in taxes and surcharges on a flight to Athens in September .
For us on the west coast , it is better for us to book our air directly .
We have just been enquiring about our flights to Paris , and the taxes , surcharges , etc. is $ 362 .
I also booked mine independently from Insight using my travel agent and saved quite a bit .
The flights were identical to what Insights have to offer so connections and arrival airport pickups were no problem .
On a previous trip I used airline points because it was a guaranteed departure date .

However , I booked my most recent flight with Insight because the departure date was NOT guaranteed and cancellation insurance would have cost about $ 300 more to cover me for non-medical type of cancellations .
If you do book your own airfare , be sure you do n't have problems if Insight has to cancel the tour or reschedule it .
Any chance it could be because the European currency has grown so much stronger ?
I know the Canadian dollar is higher than the US now and some of us had hoped for breaks as a result but the euro keeps going up as well and you 're heading to Europe ?
In any case , your travel agent can usually do better for you on price and routing .
I appreciate the responses ... after much inquiring and frustration , I am happy to say that the price is much closer to the borchure price now .
It sounded as though it was part confusion , part inexperience etc but it should turn out in the end .
Thanks to all those who took the time to respond to my initial angry post !
We are looking at our options for traveling to France in September 2008 .
We have been on 4 Insight tours and have been very happy with all of them .
So it would take a lot to make us consider another company .
But we really want to see the Bayeux tapestry and Insight does n't include it in Normandy , Brittany and the Loire Valley .
Is it worth changing to Globus who do a similar tour that does include Bayeux or can anyone suggest a daytrip from Paris that we could add to the Insight Tour ?
I would say Globus is on par with Insight .
We took a trip with them and were happy .
We like Insight a little better though .
More room on the bus .
Why not travel with Trafalgar , Insight 's sister company ?
They go to Bayeux and the other places as well .
We went with them a couple years ago and saw the tapestry , Normandy and Loire Valley and I consider them more on a par with Globus than Insight who I consider a premium company to both .
We prefer Insight because of the roomier coaches but would certainly travel again with Globus .
We chose Insight over Globus because of the itinerary , ironically on the Normandy and Loire Valley tour .
At that time , Insight went to Bayeux and had preferable Normandy sites my husband wanted to visit .
As far as quality , the companies were actually very close in our experience .
We choose by itinerary .
Thankyou South , bill and Gertie for your replies .
We 're tossing up between Globus and Trafalgar .
We 'll probably go with Trafalgar because they have listed guaranteed tours for next September .
We 'll miss the extra space of Insight though - my husband is 6ft 2 and has to sit with his legs out in the aisle on normal buses .
It 's good to know your opinion of Globus .
The Bulletin boards operated by Insight and Trafalgar give me extra confidence in both of them because I can read about other peoples ' experiences - good and bad .
Stay with Insight and when in Angers see the Apocalypse tapestry in the Angers castle ... it is 103 metres long and you will not be disappointed .
Research this and I 'm sure you 'll find it satisfactory .
The entry cost to the castle was 7.50 euro in June this year .
I thought it quite outstanding .
Can anyone please share their experiences \/ suggestions for a Winter tour in Europe -LRB- UK , France , Italy -RRB- .
Any clothing and packing suggestions ?
In a nutshell , the weather in Europe in winter will be similar to what you are used to in New Jersey .
In December , the sun wo n't be up until 9 or 10 in the morning , and it will be dark by 4 in the afternoon .
The Christmas markets are a lot of fun , if you are there in December .
After the Christmas season , there are n't as many tourists , so the places you visit will be less crowded .
But , some attractions are not open in the off season , or they run on a reduced schedule .
So , sometimes you ca n't do as much .
You just have to be flexible .
That 's a very broad question .
I have been in Europe a few times in December , and once in March .
I enjoyed every trip , but sometimes the weather does n't cooperate .
Appreciate it Bob .
got your point .
We booked for Winter explorer starting Nov 15th .
When at the AutoGrille ... keep an eye on your smaller purchases .
The cashier will tend to slide them to the side with the intent that you will forget to pick up the item .
They will only bag and slide across items on the counter for native Italians only .
Examine your receipts carefully while at the AutoGrille ... the cashier will , if he\/she can get away with it , short-change you big time .
Ladies MUST wear their bags across their chest , not have the strap around their shoulder .
While in the more crowded areas of cities such as Venice , there were bold attempts to either take the wallet , or the entire bag from the female tour member .
Incidently , my wife and I are 3rd generation Italians , and are writing this without prejudice .
Also , for those who do not know , the `` AutoGrilles '' are the Hi-Way restaurant chain seen along the AutoStrada throughout most of Italy .
We wanted to pass along the following TIPS to fellow travelers in the interest of being aware of common practices among Service Personnel -LRB- and Others -RRB- while traveling in Italy .
These TIPS are not all inclusive , and are to be considered preliminary .
These scenarios did happen , and are identified here to HELP INSIGHT travelers avoid encountering them .
Above all ... .
enjoy yourself and have a safe , and memorable tour .
When you land in Italy , if there is an official\/semi-official person in the baggage area asking you for your name and hotel , do not give it to them !
I would like to add an airport tip .
The lady came up to me and asked me for my name and hotel .
I asked why .
She did n't answer and moved on to the older guy standing next to me who she assumed was my dad -LRB- I was traveling alone -RRB- because we were chatting .
She told him that half the luggage had n't made it from Heathrow , so if we could give her our name and hotel , she would arrange the luggage to be sent to us there .
First of all , the luggage had n't even finished unloading .
No Airline , especially British Airways is that pro-active .
Luckily , I spotted my bag and warned the guy that she was trying to scam him , either into another hotel or to separate him from his baggage so her colleagues could pick it over .
Hi , I 'm going to travel to Egypt in December 2007 .
Since I 'm from tropical weather country , I have no idea how cold is it in Egypt during winter season -LRB- during December -RRB- .
The places that I 'm going to visit are Cairo , Alexandria , Luxor , Aswan and I 'll be on cruise for 3 days .
Kindly advice what kind of clothing should I bring during the visit for daylight and night .
As far as I know , there will be a big temperature variance during daylight and night in Egypt .
I think it is a little cool in the evenings so I am bringing a med weight sweater ... we live in Florida so it will probably feel downright cold to me .
Hey Cindytg - What tour are you taking and when in Dec ?
I am on EE , Dec 24 .
Take something warm to wear as Cairo can get quite cold in December .
Thanks a lot for the replies and advices = -RRB- .
I 'm joining Malaysia Egypt tour on 20th December .
It 's a 10 days 8 nights tour .
I am really looking forward for the trip
My husband and I are going on tour to Monte Carlo , Tuscany and Rome .
What is the dress code the the casino in Monte Carlo ?
- has anyone got suggestions ?
Also we are going to have to arrange our own transportation from our hotel in Rome to the airport .
Any suggestions other than the usual cab ride and does what about the cost ?
We had no problem getting into the lowere part of the casino in just the casual clothes were were wearing for our day 's travel .
We visited the Monte Carlos Casino on our way to Nice .
If you want to enter the proper Casino part , then you must present your passport , pay the number of Euros -LRB- sorry ca n't remember the amount and men must wear a tie and jacket .
We were there in August .
Does anyone know of a pub that will be showing AFL -LRB- football -RRB- in London next Saturday as we will be in London before our trip starts .
We 'll be in Budapest for the Grand Final .
I think hubby will have to set the recorder .
When we were in London last month a lot of the pubs had signs out the front about the Rugby but nothing about league or AFL .
They are pretty friendly though and I 'm sure if you asked at any `` local '' they would be able to tell you where you could catch the game .
Go NQ Cowboys !
Thanks for your answer Bellbird its a bit far to go to Edinburgh just to watch footy .
We will enjoy our trip only one more sleep , this time tomorrow we will be at the airport , cases are packed and locked and after 12 months planning it is finally happening !
Hi Folks any one recently been to Morocco like the last few weeks and did you feel safe there we be ther the next few days well 30 Days looking forward to it .
And just one more Question Ricks Cafe is it far from Royal Mansour Meridien Hotel as we we will be doing a pretor thats the first place on our list .
We visited Morocco in January and found it to be very safe .
We recommend that you are careful but it is safe .
The restaurant is small and the food is ok and expensive .
We recommend having a drink at the bar and then walking to a restaurant less than a block away .
It is a Moroccan restuarant in a Portuguese fortress .
The food is good .
I would take a cab .
Before you enter the cab , be sure to say `` le metre '' the meter
If not , you should negotiate the price before entering the cab .
Write the price down on a piece of paper .
The cab driver might try to ask you for more money .
However , this is the `` Moroccan '' way of things .
We were never cheated because we were always firm with the price .
Walk the Corniche .
The ability to speak French will be a big help .
We visited Rick 's Cafe .
Other things to do in Casablanca ,
Be sure to get your picture taken with one of the waiters .
quote : Originally posted by John J Ebbs :
We were to Rick 's cafe on October 27 , 2005 for an included tour drink .
Definitely take a tour inside the Hassan II mosque .
It 's really amazing and the tours are well done .
They are well worth the money .
Am considering this tour for Dec 22-31 .
Anyone done this tour of Morocco at or about that time of year ?
What is average weather like ?
Is the country expensive , i.e. meals , drinks , etc. ?
Any input and advice is appreciated .
My mum and I are doing in 3 weeks or so .
It starts on Septmber 21st , we are very excited and so looking forward to it .
I will fill you in when we get back , although you may have booked by then .
Do not drink the local water .

In Italy , the general rule of thumb about modesty for women in `` sacred '' places was covered shoulders and covered knees .
I wore blouses with sleeves and cropped pants  below the knee every where .

Because I am uneasy about having our debit cards with us on our upcoming trip to Italy , I got regular ATM cards .
They work on the Cirrus and Pulse networks , just like our debit cards , but can only be used at ATM 's with a PIN -- not to make purchases like a debit card .
Is there any reason to think these wo n't work to get cash from the ATM 's just as well as the debit card ?
-LRB- We will have credit cards for purchases , too . -RRB-
I think you will be able to cash with them , but you will be charged interest on the cash from the time of debit , unless you put cash in before you go .
We have n't done this , however .
Has anyone else ?
Thanks for the quick reply .
But there wo n't be an interest charge .
The money comes out of our checking or savings accounts just like a debit card .
I 'm sure the machine would charge a transaction fee .
My only concern is that they wo n't work simply because they are n't full fledged debit cards , just simple ATM-only cards .
My Atm card worked fine in Spain and Portugal .
I have an ATM card which is not a debit card .
I do n't use a debit card , I prefer to pay with Mastercardso I get airmiles .
We have the bank ATM card as you state no VISA , etc debit  just the bank name and have used it at Cirrus and Pulse networks in several countries in Europe without any problem .
All the machines required a 4 digit numerical pin , did not show alphas .
I do n't believe , however , that we used it when we were in Italy .
Our bank card IS our debit card , and we were charged a fee for withdrawals .
However , we got a better exchange rate for the cash than at a currency exchange .
You are correct that I was confused above ; the interest goes on if we get cash from our credit card , not the bank card .
Thanks to all for the helpful comments .
I think I 'll be all set with the ATM cards .

Could someone please tell me how much taxi fares cost in Italy ... or how do i know im not being ripped off !
I have a free day before the tour starts and wish to use a taxi ... do you have to hail the taxi or do you have to book one ?
The cab went from the hotel to the airport .
It cost us 44 euros to drive to the airport which is what I was told .
Some people in our group on the tour used cabs and we heard good things and bad things about the rates .
But if you can get a quote from your hotel about what the costs should be it gives you a chance to pick the right cab .
We only used a cab one time in Rome .
I asked the hotel 's desk clerk how much it should cost to go to the airport .
I asked the cabby as we got in if the price to the aiport quoted me was correct and he said yes .
we used a taxi quite a bit in Rome before and after our tour and found most taxi fares to be cheap and fair .
The cost sitting about 5 to 12 euros depending upon destination .
The longest one was 15 Euro , ie Colossum area to Castle St Anglo Vatican City area.
The airport to Rome is about 45 Euro , however on arrival we prebooked a limo from the hotel

Mind you a limo in Rome is a big car like a Statemans and were charged 50 euro which we consider fair for the ease of having been met at the airport with someone holding our name and after a long flight from OZ we really did appreciate that .
There are special ranks for taxis , which we did use however , hailing off the street was also no problem , but I do believe it was n't totally legal .
But we had no problem in May this year .
I also found the taxi fare whilst on tour at various villages would be dear for the little distance traveled .
At Villages or small towns it seemed that they charged a rate per person rather than distance , when a maxi cab was hired by the tour director at the stops .
All in all individual cost was about 2 Euro .
Enjoy your trip and hold your breath for a taxi in Rome is one hell of a hectic ride often the air was filled with the driver cursing !

We Too were told you could be ripped off however ,

I have taken a natural supplement overseas with me before .
I took it to my doctor and they added it to my list of medications that I carried on their letterhead .
Noone even looked at it .
I generally just pack them in my checked in baggage , I have never had a problem in the past .
If you are unsure , you should be able to pick them up in any chemist or heath shop once you arrive .
On my last trip , because of all the liquid scares etc , I did leave everything at home and bought all my vitamins etc. from Boots once I arrived in London .
I packed the leftovers in my suitcase to come home and there were no problems .

Have a great safe time and let us know how it went when safely home .
We have taken natural suppliments with us eg Healtheries products , garlic tabs etc in original bottles .
Always taken them in our carry on in a clear zip lock bag the same as the liquids .
Never had a problem , never been asked .

Never got asked .
There is always a possibility of being questioned , one never knows when it could be .

As tipping is not common in Australia I am wondering if all travellers pay the amount suggested ?
Do you think this tip should be paid for the first and last say which are often only a meal and a greeting ?
The tip is usually paid at the end of the tour , usually the last evening , or this has been the case on the tours I have done .
It is really up to you how much you give and when you decide to give it .
I think the suggested amounts are fair .
The tours I have done , the tour director and the driver have gone above and beyond the call of duty .
Go to FIND and type in `` tipping . ''
You will find loads of entries about tipping .
You have to be logged in and FIND is right above the entries .
As September points out , you 'll find lots of comments about tipping if you do a search .
When I 'm tipping , I count up the number of days that I had something to do with the TD and bus driver .
If we had days at leisure and the driver had nothing to do with my on those days because I did n't take any of the optionals , I consider that when calculating my tip .
If I only saw the TD at the get acquainted meeting on the first day and if he just said good-bye on the last day , I count those 2 days as one .
However , as for the amount of the tip , sometimes I tip less because service was n't what I had hoped for and sometimes I tip more because service was exceptional .
Having the guide provided by Insight allows me to budget how much cash to have available for the end of the trip .
As for your question about the first and last day , I take those into consideration .

I am trying to prepare myself for sending mail back home during our Eurpoean Heritage trip .

Can someone advise me on postage to Aussie e.g. Does each European country have their own stamps and postage rates and not a common postage like the Euro currency ; are postage stamps readily available in Insight hotels ; is there a `` standard '' postcard size that will fit in a common envelope that I could have preaddressed etc. .
Each country has their own postage system and cost for postage varies .
In my experience the rate for postcards is specific to postcards , and does n't allow for an envelope .
You could try risking it , but no guarantees that it will arrive at the other end .
Maybe you could use stickers that you have pre-addressed and stick onto the postcard .
You could even print them up on a computer - no excuses for the mail people not reading your handwriting then !
As far as hotels having stamps - most will , but no guarantees in some of the countries you 're going to .
I 'm sure the tour director would be able to help you with that though - and you can always post things from the next stop .
Might be quicker sometimes - not all countries have the same time waits on postage .
Aust post you will come to see is really quite good compared to some !
Just getting back to cost - we usually find that the stamps cost us more than the postcards !
And sizes of cards can vary from one place to another - just like they do vary here in OZ depending on who produces them or who the photographer is .
Hi MaurJoy , would n't it be nice if there was an easy way to buy lots of stamps at once to mail through the tour - but sadly no. .
I usually print off a couple of label sheets , with the addresses of the family
A bit of a time saver and I can also see at a glance who I have sent a postcard too .

can anyone advise us on the best way of visiting the vatican museums ?
We have seen many and varying types of tours including TuscanyAllShould we pre book a tour 0r just queue up on the day .
We will be in Rome in late September .
If you are doing an Insight Tour , I would definately recommend you take their optional tour on this one .
Otherwise you will need to be up really really early , the queue 's are massive .
I went last year , they allow the tour groups in earlier , but you still queue or an hour or so .
I know some people on our tour chose to do this tour themselves , but ended up not doing it all when they saw the size of the queue .
Once inside , it is quite hard to move around as it is very busy , hang on to your belongings , pick pockets are rife here .
Beware also the tour guide often holds up a newspaper so you can follow him , but take a tip from me , get a good look at him and do n't ever lose sight , they nearly all hold up a newspaper !
Alternatively try as much as possible to stay together as a group .
If you do choose to do this alone , you wo n't have to worry about any of this .
Whatever you do though , do go , it is a once in a lifetime opportunity for some of us , and will become a treasured holiday memory .
You can also book a tour with a Vatican guide who will take you around or you can go around by yourself .
Whichever method you choose , you 'll likely not get to see eveything because there is just so much !
Line-ups get worse late morning to mid-afternoon .
I 've seen people just waltz in after 3:00 , but you never can tell what the line-ups are going to be like from one day to the next .
I booked an appointment with a Vatican guide and also visited the museum with the Insight guide .
It turned out to be a great way to do it because I got 2 different perspectives ; one guide was an artist and the other was an anthropologist with an interest in architecture .
Like the Louvre , the Vatican Museum requires multiple visits .
However I 'll have to go back -LRB- aw shucks ! -RRB-
to see everything that I did n't get a chance to see the first time around .

I have recently had hip and knee surgery , beginning to wonder about access to bus .
How steep are the steps ?
Yikes , Well , there are two sets of stairs on the bus ... front and back .
The front are a lot easier -LRB- less steep and much easier to climb  than the back .
However , your TD will ask people seated in the back to use the back steps and those in front of the back steps to use the front steps .
This allows the bus to load and unload a lot easier .
Each day your seat assignment will rotate .
My advice , check out the back steps when you get picked up at the airport .
At the welcome drink perhaps you could request with your TD to be seated in the front section so you can you the easier steps .
I do n't know which tour you are contemplating , but on some European tours the steps on the coach would be the least of your worries .
I do n't wish to be discouraging , but I think that you need to pick your tour carefully .
It turned out the seat at the back was the best for him because it was actually the most spacious .
If you 've recently had surgery you 're probably going to want to stretch that side out more often than the 2 hours between rest stops .
Some of the newer buses are `` kneeling '' coaches and the driver can actually lower the front of the bus to make getting on and off more easy .
Be sure to make your Tour Director aware of your situation .
As Tangata says , depending on the tour you 've booked , coach access may be the least of your problems .
For example , some of the smaller towns in Italy can not be reached by coach and we walk up the small and winding roads to the town .
I was on tour once where one of the passengers had an artificial limb and needed to be able to have that leg out in the aisle .
I 've found that there 's usually a solution to these types of problems .

We may be taking our family on a trip to enjoy the beautiful colors of Fall and have narrowed our research down to Michigan and New Hampshire .
Any recommendations about which of these two regions would offer the best foliage ?
We 'll probably be doing a lot of country road driving .
You will probably get more answer if you repost this is the U.S. Forum and tag it for Michigan and New Hampshire .
Sorry I ca n't offer more help .
The routes we 've found to be the best are M-22 and M-119 .
M-22 starts in Manistee which is on the Lake Michigan coastline .
You can follow M-22 north along the coast and it brings you back down into Traverse City .
This is a very popular route for color tours in Michigan .
Part of M-22 runs through Sleeping Bear Dunes which was voted as `` America 's Most Beautiful Place '' on Good Morning America ... this is a very cool and scenic area .
Traverse City is also a very beautiful town and a great place to spend the night after a day of driving .
From there you can continue on US-31 which takes you around the east bay of Grand Traverse bay and north past Torch Lake which was also voted one of the most beautiful lakes in the US.
Keep heading north on 31 and you will go through Charlevoix and Petoskey very nice cities to stop for lunch and go for a walk .
After you go through Petoskey look for M-119 .
M-119 is about 20 miles long and has been nicknamed `` the tunnel of trees '' , this road is a spectacular drive any time of year but is at it 's best in the fall months for the color tours .
I 'm from Michigan and we do the color tour thing every year .
Hope this helps !
Vermont has the most intense colors .
A drive up Rt .100 is a great way to see them at their best .
Thank you , all .
I put my vote in for New Hampshire .
The South , Georgia and Tennessee can also have beautiful fall foliage .

I would like to recommend NOT using the super shuttle services, at least not in paris where we used them and were very disappointed .
My wife and I pre-ordered the super shuttle services online .
When we landed yesterday in paris , we called them and they said they will dispatch a shuttle right away and it will arrive in 5 minutes .
If we would have known we at least would have had the option to decide whether we want to stay and keep on waiting or leave earlier with another company or service .
Another family with kids that waited with us , finally decided to quit and left after half an hour .
If I had known that this is the type of service that we will receive I would never have booked them from the beginning .
I 've used shuttle services many times in in Paris to\/from CDG and Orly , and have never had a problem .
One bad experience does not a bad company make .
I just came back from Paris two days ago and had used Super Shuttle .

I prebooked but found upon landing that due to construction at the terminal and waiting forever on the phone to reconfirm from baggage claim that it was very confusing  and I work as a flight attendant so am used to European limo services on a regular basis .
I finally got a ride from them only after an hour and then waiting for another 20 minutes while they picked someone else up at another terminal .
The return ride was prompt however we stopped to pick up several other people so an extra 45 minutes were added on to my original pickup time of 630am .
I think that if you are traveling as a single it is more economical but if there are more than two traveling just take a taxi .
My friend and I are flying -LRB- hopefully first class -RRB- from Florida to Florence and returning from Rome .
We 're closer to Ft. .
Lauderdale , but Miami ok .
Do n't want to make more than 1 stop .
You are n't going to find direct flights from either airport .
Fort Lauderdale represents itself as an international airline , but it 's mostly to Central and South America .
Miami will have more options .
Only one airline flies nonstop to Rome , which is Alitalia .
The Florence airport is a regional airport .
You 'll find lots of international flights going to from Bologna , then a short train ride down to Florence .
Try asking on the airlines board .
Use Change Forum above .
Also not every airline flies a first class .
Some max out at Business .
Your best bets are Lufthansa or Swiss .
Both offer 1-stop flights to Florence or Rome from Miami , both offer first class , and both have superb F products .
I prefer Swiss 's inflight first class , but Lufthansa 's F ground services are probably the best of any airline , anywhere .

My husband and I have never used a travel agent before -LRB- aside from work travel -RRB- and have generally been happy and excited to plan our own travel .
However , now that we have kids , we do n't have the time to do lots of travel planning so we 're considering using a travel agent .
We do n't want to do group tours but are mainly interested in having someone help plan a rough agenda for us , book hotels , car rentals\/car services , etc. .

Does it make sense to work with local travel agents in the country we plan to visit , realizing we 'd have to find new agents each trip or should we find a US-based agent and work with them on an on-going basis ?
Any advice or tips are appreciated !
We use a US based Travel Agent who has helped us plan several trips all over the world .
He 's associated with Virtuoso Travel a world wide association of over 7200 agents in 20 countries and calls upon `` experts '' in the different countries we visited to help plan itineraries .
He 's helped put together some very special and detailed trips for us .
A god travel agent gets to know you , your likes and dislikes and can tailor a trip to meet your specific needs .

Now , we make basic travel plans such as trips to see relatives and shot vacations to places we are familiar with , on our own but when we want something special , including trips to new countries or complex trips that include numerous travel legs , private tours , speciality hotels\/resorts , etc then we definitely use our Travel Agent .
So , check around and find yourself a professional TA who does more than just book hotels .
Sounds to me like a TA shill .
Only post , period .
Because Fodor 's is a website specifically designed for and frequented mostly by self-planners , you do n't usually get much feedback about the `` using a travel agent '' type questions .
To me , SnappyGo looks like a nice in-between a full-service travel agent and doing it yourself .
I believe it 's fairly new and I 've never tried it myself , though .

I usually buy a SIM when I get in Country but if you 're hopping around Europe you have to get one in each Country or pay the roaming rates on the one you 've got when get to a new Country .
But when your SIM runs our of credit you ca n't buy more credit for it in another country , so you 'd have to get a new one .
They have multi-country SIM cards that work everywhere .
I have a National Geographic one , but the rates on it are n't as good as local Country SIMs , but you do n't have to keep switching .
I 'll gladly pay the prevailing rates for long distance not to carry a cell phone with me .
The point of going on holiday is just that , a holiday from the everyday world .
One does not need instant communication 24x365 .
I run from the thought of that happening to me .
EU Law dictates that you ca n't be charged xxx amounts of money while roaming ... That being said , I 've had good coverage with O _•À___ , owned by Telefonica .

I have heard bad things about their customer service  indeed , in their case , I should n't have to pay to call their customer service , yet I do , but still , you do n't pay for calls received , just made.

The worst thing would be to try and top up what they call refilling your credit with notes , since they only take British Credit\/Debit Cards when topping up by phone , since more than likely , you 'll be on prepaid .
They usually include x amounts of minutes to a select number of countries , the US included when I was there last in July ' 11 , they had like 100 minutes included when I topped up # 15 .
Also , if you 're going to be in London , do n't forget to get a Transport for London Card .
Even if you 're going to be there a few days , it does save some money and you can use it on the Tube and iconic Double Decker Buses .

I 've read about one cruiser who brought along an inexpensive over-the-door shoe bag to hold all the toiletries , but what about something to use IN the shower to avoid leaving containers on the shower floor ?
I generally travel with those wonderful gadgets with suction cups but am not sure of the surface of the shower walls from ship to ship .

I 'd use the suction-cup thing .
I 've never encountered a shower stall in a cruise ship that was n't smooth enough to hold one of the suction cups .

It 's not a very busy forum , but I 'd also post this on the Cruise forum .

I think the cruise shower caddy by Favors By Serendipity is perfect .

I agree , post on the Cruise forum , hardly anyone reads this `` Travel Tips '' branch .
I have a number of small plastic mesh bags with a drawstring similar to this : http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-AmlzVCxXDKs/TGJYOV-o51I/AAAAAAAAASI/cyV53ccSFUc/s1600/mesh.jpg
Instead of a plastic grocery bag , you could hang one or more of those on a suction cup hook .
A fabric mesh bag , like you use for lingerie in a washing machine .
How long are you traveling for that you can not live without a shower caddy ?
However , I 'm glad it did because I 've always found it a pain being in a shower that did n't have shelving .
You have to worry about your soap dish filling with water and bending down to pick up stuff which is sometimes awkward depending on the size of shower.
A mesh bag and suction cup take up so little room that I 've added them to my toiletries kit .
Until this thread came up , I would n't have thought of bringing something to keep my shower items off the floor .
So , even if I was going only overnight , it 's worth it to me .
It 's not a matter of the length of the trip IMO .
I have experimented with various travel things that had a suction cup attached , but found , for whatever reasons , I kept leaving them in the hotel room .
My all time favorite item , an unbreakable 10X mirror , 4 inches in diameter which sticks right onto the big mirror for putting on mascara or contact lenses I have replaced no less than thrice .
So a shower caddy would only be good for one trip for me !
For some reason my eyes do n't see things on vertical surfaces when I scan the room to see if I 've forgotten anything .
I have a hanging , multipocket mesh organizer which has a hook to hang it from the shower head arm .
I think I bought it at a dollar store .
It works very well .

I just want to let everybody know about the Worldwide Survival Conference , an event being hosted by S4C - The Sri Lanka Community Centre Construction Corps - A UK-based charity aiming to raise funds to build a large community center in Matale , Sri Lanka to provide jobs and facilities for victims of the 2004 Asian Tsunami who are still suffering in from the fallout of the disaster , most of whom are living in a nearby Red Cross-run refugee camp .
A must attend Conference for anyone who wants to gain more Confidence , learn new ways to look after themselves , colleagues , family and friends at travel or work anywhere in the World .

The Worldwide Survival Conference offers an all-day event from 10am to 6pm , with tea , coffee and a buffet lunch , a fun day and several useful and interesting seminars for the frequent traveller or tourist , whether on or off-the beaten track including :
Tips and advice for working and traveling in remote areas , by veteran globe-trotter Mark Callow of GOMAD .
Dealing with major wounds and injuries
By the British Red Cross
Personal protection , Self defense and bodyguarding family and friends
by Clive Whitworth of the Intensive Training Group
Use of basic weapons to protect yourself against knife or machete attack
by Gary Alderman European Escrima\/Kali and Stick fighting champion Gary Alderman
There will be an exhibition of guns , weapons and mines from all over the world and a Specialist to give you information on how to disarm them and their properties .
Also Julie Thompson from Bedford Hypnosis and NLP will be there to give you some tools to help prepare yourself for a Crisis or conflict and cope with Post Incident Stress .
There will be time for questions and answers with the experts after the talks and demonstrations .
More details and ticket booking can be found at http://www.eventbrite.com/event/2816021797
Also more information on S4C and it 's mission can be found at www.SriLanka4c.com

I `` self-insure '' plane and hotel costs .
I generally self-insure tours , in the rare cases I take one , although Rick Steves ' tours include cancellation\/interruption insurance in the price .

If you could n't afford to `` eat '' any costs for travel or accommodations that you could n't cancel without penalty you should consider insurance , but read the conditions carefully and do n't buy from an outfit that is providing the service you 're covering .
I make sure my medical insurance covers me abroad.
if you are a US senior be aware that Medicare does not -RRB- , but ALWAYS take out medical evacuation insurance .
Lately I 've been dealing with Seven Corners for that .
What kind of insurance do you want ?
I paid less than $ 200 for medical and trip cancellation insurance to cover the prepaid costs of this trip with TravelSafe , purchased through www.squaremouth.com .
We were reimbursed $ 250 per person to change our tickets as well as a $ 350 copay per person for one way upgrades to Biz Class on American and $ 150 pp to redeposit the miles for the upgrade .
All we had to do was provide the required documentation and an Attending Physician 's Statement and received a check within a couple of weeks .
I guess we could have `` self insured '' but we 'd have been out $ 1300 .
We 've taken trip insurance for our last 4 trips due to the advanced age of my mother in law and the fact that we are n't getting younger either .
Sure enough , in 2010 my husband came down with pancreatitis and we had to postpone our European trip .
And , since my mother in law is still with us at 90 yrs old , we will continue to take out insurance on future trips .
It gives us peace of mind which is why you get insurance in the first place .

I agree that if you are going to insure your trip , you need to look at the risk vs. cost - how much money would you lose if you canceled and are you ok with that , versus how much the insurance would cost .
For me , the math has n't worked out - we have never prepaid enough to warrant buying the insurance .
We do buy a travel medical plan because our primary medical does n't cover us out of the country .

Yes exactly that , but the hand luggage has to be a backpack or similar .
Trolley cases can not fit in overhead compartment , of bus .
Some people had them on our tour , because they had not received their tickets and tour info , till it was almost time for departure .
Their bags went in with the suitcases , so they did not have access to them , whilst we were on the `` road '' .
The size restrictions are all listed in the Insight brochures .
`` Remember a tour is not a vacation , it is a tour ''
I have a 4 wheeled walker with a seat and hand brakes that I use when I have a lot of walking to do .
We are doing the Country Roads of Switzerland Sept. 19th .
I was wondering how many cobblestone streets there would be and if putting the walker on the trains would be a problem .
I also will have my cane along for times when the walker wo n't really be practical .
I have not done the CR of Switzerland - have done CR of France , Ireland and Italy but I think that you may find that you are limited in what you can do and where you can go .
In the 5 tours that I have done , I can only remember one lady with a walker and I do recall she was limited in her activities - spent some time in a cafe instead of exploring .
I 'm not sure if that was her or the walker that needed a break .
They were all however limited to where they could go as many of the old buildings we visited did not have lifts and had a lot of stairs .
On one trip there were five ladies who were not able to walk up hills so the tour director had to order two taxis for them as they could not all fit into one .
This was done at their own expense as Insight does not pay for this .
It worked out quite epensive in the long run as this was the Country Roads of Italy tour where there were a lot of hills to walk up .
The ladies did however enjoy the tour and did see as much as was possible because the tour director was very , very helpful .
The lady on the mobility scooter unfortunately missed out on quite a lot , this was an Easy Pace Tour of Italy two years ago .
There were problems with being able to charge up the mobility scooter , so she was stuck with not being able to walk .
Lenore , I have not done the tour you are doing , but I have done a lot of tours with Insight .
I have been on tours where there have been people with wheelchairs , walking canes , one lady even had a mobility scooter .
I do hope that all goes well for you , I have to say that I admire anyone who has the desire to travel , regardless of their mobility issues .
All the best to you .
Life 's a journey not a destination - Aerosmith , Amazing
The problem there was the speed of the tours .
I 'll be sure to take along my seated cane for when there are a lot of stairs .
Thank you for your input .
I did the Country Roads of Italy and Sicily , but used my cane .
I need to sit quite freqently so could n't keep up .
I can do the stair and use the cane for assistance and sitting at the top .

Be aware that hotel wireless might not always work on your smart phone .
It might be good to travel with a small laptop or do research on your phone 's specifications before you leave .
Although technologies change very quickly , it would have been good for us to know some of the issues that could arise before we departed on our trip .
In our trip to Italy over the past 3 weeks , at 2 of our 5 hotels we were unable to log in to the hotel 's free wireless service using our HTC Desire Android phones purchased in North America .
The wireless network did not even show up as an available network in our hotel room .
However , in both cases we WERE able to access the wireless network from our room using our laptop computer .
Luckily we could set up a tethering system by plugging our phones into the laptop one by one , using its internet connection .
The problem may be due to the signal strength demanded by the phone 's wireless system -LRB- compared to the computer 's -RRB- , and walls could get in the way and reduce signal strength .
Some hotels had an internet wireless connection for each floor of the building .

In one hotel we could access the wireless network directly by phone only when sitting on a chair in the ground-floor hallway next to the room that broadcast the wireless frequency ; anything farther away would lose connection .

However , at this same hotel , when in our room our phones detected secure networks for nearby hotels across the street -LRB- it was in downtown Florence -RRB- and our laptop could access the wireless network .
The hotel staff said that they have occasionally encountered this issue with guests ' smart phones .
It was nice that they supplied a computer in each room that worked on wireless technology , but its Microsoft Windows interface was Italian and we preferred to use our own computer and its programs .
When we arrived at home , we did some internet research on this and discovered that part of the issue might be the telephone 's specifications .
This page by HTC has some information on the model of HTC Desire we used : http://www.htc.com/www/smartphones/htc-desire-hd/#specs .
The page currently lists different networks for Europe and Asia Pacific -LRB- HSPA\/WCDMA : 900\/2100 MHz ; GSM : 850\/900\/1800 \/ 1900 MHz -RRB- but does not list info for North America .
My husband had discovered somewhere else online that different HTC models are sold in Europe and North America and this may make it work differently when crossing regions .

Would like to know if the carry on bag on the bus would be safe while we are off the bus , example if we keep meds in that case or should we keep in big suitcase which will be underneath , Thanks and looking forward to trip in 3 weeks
I tend to take enough for a day or two with me wherever I go in a small ` carry about ' and the rest goes in the main case or even in a regular carry-on under the bus .

I once asked a TD about the safety of doing that and the reply was that there was more likelihood of somebody stealing the entire bus than a case , albeit overnight when we and our cases are not in it .

If you think you may wish to do the same then bring a letter from your doctor detailing the meds you need just in case replacement is needed as many items can not be openly purchased in Europe as they are in the USA .
That is a tricky one as it rather depends on your ` meds ' and where you are going .
Any questions so far ... ?
Thank you , appreciate your help
As the Tour Director 's and the Driver 's personal things are also left on the bus you can rest assured that they keep it safe !
-LRB- During the day , that is - do n't leave anything on the bus overnight -RRB- .
Thank you , this is very reassuring
One more thing to keep in mind if your tour includes Venice .
The big Insight bus can not make it to the Hotel to unload luggage .
Instead they have to shuttle your luggage between the bus and the hotel .
Because of this , they will ONLY transport your one large piece of luggage .
Any hand luggage you bring on the trip either has to stay on the bus overnight or be carried with you all day .
I swapped out the things I was keeping in my hand luggage -LRB- my medication -RRB- for that part of the trip only .
Since I had read different opinions regarding the size of hand luggage before leaving on my trip , I was really curious what the truth was .
Most people brought small hand luggage or a backpack that fit under their seat .
There was plenty of room under the bus -LRB- a separate section just for hand luggage -RRB- for roller bags .
But our tour director confirmed that there would NOT be enough room if everyone brought overnight roller bags .
Very helpful , fortunately not Venice this time .

I have never attended Fan Fair , but I traveled through one time enroute to a funeral and could not find an open hotel room for 100 miles on either side of Nashville , so believe it when people say you have to book ahead .
I see the tickets for the concerts for June 7-10 , 2012 go on sale next week and the tour operators are taking deposits now for ticket\/accommodation packages .
The only transit I know of is the usual public bus system and a free shuttle among the venues , but not to area hotels .
Some hotels offer their own transportation .
Taxis are an option .
So whether you will need a car while in Nashville will depend on where you stay .
Factor any transport offered by a hotel into the alternative cost of renting a house .
There are some tour operators offering bus trips to Dollywood and\/or Memphis .
There is no rail and the long-distance bus option is not very good .
For example , Nashville to Memphis takes 4 hours with 3-4 buses per day at a cost of around $ 50 per person .
Then you would need a car or taxi to get to Graceland and other sights .
You could also fly between Nashville and Memphis , but you 'd need ground transport once in town .

Dollywood is in a small town not served directly by an airport or the bus as far as I know, so driving the 3.5 hours would get you there as opposed to flying into Knoxville and having to drive from there .
Hiring a vehicle large enough for 6 minivan ?
for the road trip east to Dollywood and\/or Southwest to Memphis is probably best if one of the tours does not match your interest .
Maybe there a place on the Fan Fare website where people with more experience discuss the details and give hints\/advice ?
On Saturday we picked up a brochure that was for an $ 11 pick up with Bay Shuttle from Nobb Hill in San Francisco to the airport .
We had a flight booked for 12pm but decided to allow hours which meant we wanted to depart at 9am .
I rang the company on Saturday and went ahead and booked our transfer to the airport for the Monday to come .
Monday morning came and so did 9am .
By 9.15 am we were a tad bit concerned .
I called the company and was told that no booking had been made under our name and no car was scheduled to come and pick us up .
Luckily we were in a good area and a taxi was available to take us to the airport .
Very disorganised and clearly wasnt paying much attention over the phone when the booking was made .
I pretty much use taxis now for home pickup but still use the airport shuttles that make regular rounds of the hotels .
I 've had that happen before with a door-to-door shuttle .
Its so frustrating isnt it ?
We are lucky we had left plenty of time but someone else may not be so lucky next time !
I live in San Francisco , and Bay Shuttle is my favorite company !
For a few years I make my reservations on-line as they always have Internet special .
Never had a no-show , always on time or a bit early .
Our son used them too , he never complained .
I wonder if you confirmed your reservation .
But this is just me , I always confirm everything

We did the bay shuttle in San Francisco once but it did n't end up like this .

It 's not acceptable to stink people out while they are eating , no , even outdoors and even with normal cigarettes let alone cigarillos .
You are expected to show some manners and consideration .
I would n't dream of smoking near a food area and you 'll probably get told to stop if you do .
But yes , there are still plenty of us smokers around , huddling pathetically round doorways .
Likewise if you go to a park and sit on a bench , it 's impolite to sit next to a non-smoker and spark up .
You have to find an empty bench or find another smoker .
So it 's tolerated , but not too close to non-smokers .

I 'm planning a trip to Bhutan and Nepal in the fall .
The trip is pretty expensive -LRB- compared to others I 've done -RRB- and I want insurance in case I have to cancel or change for any reason .
Who can advise me on a good company to use ?
This site does a comparison of various insurnace options
it 's been written up in quite a few publications which are linked on their website .
A lot of people recommend insuremytrip.com for comparisons .
Make sure your policy includes medical -LRB- if you do n't have cover abroad -RRB- and medical evacuation and repatriation .
There 's a discussion of medevac insurance on the Asia board right now .
I concur with insuremytrip.com .
It 's a great site to compare multiple policies !
Also , be forewarned that you will be a significant premium to obtain the `` cancel for any reason '' benefit and often you will only get 50-75 % of amount back .
Also , you need to purchase insurance quickly after paying for your trip in order to get the pre-existing conditions waiver .
If you study `` cancel for any reason '' policies , the amount you 're ultimately reimbursed , provided you are within all requirements and restrictions , is about equal to the premium .
Otherwise , cancellations and\/or changes are covered only for `` covered reasons '' and you must understand the terms and conditions , and , especially , the exclusions and requirements .
It 's critical to study the actual policy\/certificate and not rely on any overview or `` examples '' .
Weather , for example , is often excluded as a covered reason if your flight is canceled , unless the entire airport is closed for a certain number of hours .
One kind of insurance that I would have to recommend would be backing up any travel documents .
It 's something I 've been doing for the last couple of months and it 's proven quite effective so far .
All you do is go to accessmyid.com and they will take the load off your mind in case you come into any trouble re : passports or medical documents being lost , stolen or copied .
As for insuremytrip.com I 've had no problems with them in the past , but you have to study all `` cancel '' policies like djkbooks said .
That 's where these guys really make there money .
It 's a kind of insurance I like to have .
We used Cambell Irvine in the UK to insure our trip to Tanzania .
They were quite a bit cheaper -- offered more coverage with fewer exclusions than any US company I found .
Good price and coverage was what I needed .
I ended up purchasing through Travel Guard .
Hopefully I do n't need to use it !

Keep it on air-plane mode until you get to a wifi zone .
Gazillions of these in London and I assume Paris is the same .

I regularly skype iphone to iphone from UK to Germany on wifi .
Its free and the quality is brilliant .
Do n't known your home country but assume it is Europe ?
It depends on the country , but still expensive .
Use Skype , although the call quality varies .
Unless you have set up your phone to push email and texts , then you are really in control of your usage .
My suggestion would be to use text messaging more than voice since it 's cheaper .
And if you really feel you need to call home to check up , then call AT
Turn this off immediately upon your return .
Where you really run up costs is in data roaming , and that 's very expensive .
Do n't put your phone in Airplane mode because that turns off all the cell features -LRB- and prevents you from getting calls -RRB- .
But keep data roaming turned off and only access the internet from a Wi-Fi hotspot -LRB- preferably a free one -RRB- .
You do n't hear nearly as many horror stories from international use as you did at one time because data roaming is turned off now initially , as is the push-email function .
Keep them that way and you should have no problems .
And tell everyone to call you only in a true emergency .

North America runs on 110 volts .
When traveling in Europe I was told to use an extra piece of equipment between the adapter and my electronics so they do n't get `` fried '' by the change in voltage .
Or at least I think that 's how it works .
It is somewhat heavy and I would rather not take it if I do n't need to .
Does anyone know more about this ?
the newer models of hair dryers , etc , have two settings , 120 and 240 v.
In Europe you can do without the transformer -LRB- that 's the extra equipment -RRB- if you can switch to 240 v -LRB- volts . -RRB-
Otherwise , you need the transformer between the NA plug and the european plug .
It depends on whether or not you have `` newer '' equipment .
Ahhhh , it 's a transformer .
I was more concerned for my camcorder , phone etc. .
Look carefully on the sides to see if you see a switch that says 120v\/240v .
Or look in the manual if you still have it , or look the model up on the web .
Pretty well all modern electronics are dual voltage so that they can handle the two different systems .
Just look at the little tag that has all the electricity information and you 'll see `` INPUT ''
Next to that you 'll likely see something like he mentioned above - 100-240v
On electronics like my netbook or PSP , it was on the little brick in the cord .
On my battery chargers for my cameras , it 's on the charger .
If you see that 100-240v under the INPUT , you wo n't get fried .
All you need is the cheap , very light weight adapter for the actual plug so that you can , essentially , put a square plug into a round socket -LRB- or vice versa -RRB- .
Exactly as Gordon has said .
Not hard to find .
of course , you have to remember to switch to 240 v when you get to Europe !
A big thank you to everyone re : this question .
I definitely do n't want to fry my electronics .

I 'm thinking to save a little money and just get him a travelcard , since I 'm thinking it 's much more likely that he 'll be going to Canada and\/or on a cruise than somewhere that requires an actual passport and we 're not completely sure he 's going anywhere !

The only thing that is giving me hesitation is the inability to fly into Mexico or the Caribbean with it , although I ca n't imagine why he 'd need too -LRB- Spring break trips would occur only over my dead body , and he 's mildly disabled and is still very childlike , so it 's very hard to imagine him traveling by himself , although he should be able to eventually -RRB- .
Are there any other pitfalls I 'm not aware of ?

Why would you need the card if you have the book ?
You get both a passport and a travel card together so you have a back-up document in case you lose the passport .
If you travel frequently overseas it 's a lot easier to have a lost or stolen passport replaced if you have a legally valid document to prove both identity an d citizenship .
But in your sons case , if you do n't plan on allowing your son to travel independently , then there 's no need to get both .
But a passport is always better than a travel card , though it 's your choice .
I 'd just say that you are cutting things awfully close , however .
Your probably going to pay expediting fees to get either document by July .
That does make sense .
We were figuring that having the travel card would make it easier to get him a passport if he needed one down the road .
I 'm hoping we 'll get away with not expediting , but we 'll see what the passport people say .

We 'd both prefer if my son could go as well , since he loves to travel , and enjoys the kind of history-focused trips my dad plans .
